text: Digital Note: If you want to use a grid to represent your thinking, you can use a "Coordinate Grid" tool or drag one of these grid backgrounds into a "Sketch" or Drawing tool.
Applications
ACE 4-1
Suppose that a square prism is inserted into a cylinder of the same height so that side and top views of the two figures look like the diagrams below.

a. If the figures are both 10 centimeters in height, what are their volumes?

b. What is the ratio of cylinder volume to prism volume?

a. Volume of the cylinder is π(32)10 ≈ 283 cm3; Volume of the square prism is 180 cm3. (Hint: Think of the square base as equal in area to a sum of 2 or 4 triangles or one 3 cm ≈ 6 cm rectangle.)

b. The ratio of cylinder volume to prism volume is π : 2 ≈ 1.57 : 1.
ACE 4-2

A popcorn vender needs to order popcorn boxes. The vendor must decide between a cylindrical box and a rectangular box (both without tops).

  • The cylindrical box has a height of 20 centimeters and a radius of 7 centimeters.
  • The rectangular box has a height of 20 centimeters and a square base with 12-centimeter sides.
  • The cost of each box is based on the amount of material needed to make the box.

The vendor plans to charge $2.75 for popcorn, regardless of the shape of the box.

a. Make a sketch of each box. Label the dimensions.

b. Find the volume and surface area of each box.

c. Which box would you choose? Give the reasons for your choice. What additional information might help you make a better decision?

b. For the cylinder, the volume is 980π ≈ 3,079 cm3; the surface area is 329π ≈ 1,034 cm2. For the square prism, the volume is 2,880 cm3; the surface area is 1,104 cm2. (Note: Neither surface area includes a top face.)

c. The cylinder holds more popcorn, so it costs more to fill. The cylinder also has less packaging and therefore costs less to buy. Additional information on the cost per square centimeter of making boxes and the cost per cubic centimeter of popcorn would help in making the choice of which box is more economical for the vendor.
ACE 4-3
A cake recipe says to use a 9 inch round pan or an 8 inch square pan. Which pan would give you a taller cake? Explain your reasoning.

9 inch round area: 4.5 • 4.5 • π = 63.6 square inches

8 inch square area: 8 • 8 = 64 square inches

The area of the base of the 9 inch round is slightly smaller. So, for the two cakes to have the same volume, the 9 inch round cake would have to be taller. The question assumes that the all the other conditions when baking the cake would be the same.
ACE 4-4

A playground ball has a diameter of 18 cm.

a. Sketch a cylinder that just fits around the playground ball and label its dimensions

b. What is the volume of the cylinder?

c. What is the volume of the ball?

b. Volume of the cylinder is 1,458π ≈ 4,580 cm3.

c. Volume of the ball is 4/3 π(93) ≈ 3,054 cm3.
ACE 4-5
Find the volume of each sphere:

a. 4/3 π(7.53) ≈ 1,767 cm3

b. 4/3 π(83) ≈ 2,145 cm3
ACE 4-6

a. Find the height of a cylinder with a radius of 3 inches and volume of 250 in.3.

b. Find the height of a cone with radius of 3 inches and volume of 250 in.3.

a. Height is approximately 8.8 inches.

b. Height is approximately 26.5 inches.
ACE 4-7

The track and field club is planning a frozen yogurt sale to raise money. They need to buy containers to hold the yogurt. The two options are the cup and cone shown below. The two containers have the same cost. The club plans to charge $1.25 for a serving of yogurt. Which container should the club buy? Explain.
Possible answer: The cone holds about 36π ≈ 113 cm3 and the cylinder 28.125π ≈ 88 cm3. The club should choose the cylindrical cup because it costs less to fill.
ACE 4-8

Watertown has three water storage tanks in different shapes: a cylinder, a cone, and a sphere. Each tank has radius of 20 feet and height of 40 feet.

a. Sketch each tank and label its dimensions.

b. Without any calculation, estimate which tank will hold the most water and which will hold the least. Explain.

c. Find the volumes of the three tanks to confirm your answer to part (b.).

b. Based on the experiment in Problem 4.2, the cylinder will hold the most water and the cone will hold the least water.

c. The volume of the cylinder is 16,000π ≈ 50,265 ft3; the volume of the sphere is about 33,510 ft3; the volume of the cone is about 16,755 ft3. These results confirm the answer to part (b.).
ACE 4-9

Chilly’s Ice Cream Parlor is known for its root beer floats.

  • The float is made by pouring root beer over 3 scoops of ice cream until the glass is filled ½ inch from the top
  • A glass is in the shape of a cylinder with a radius of 1 ¼ inches and height of 8 ½ inches
  • Each scoop of ice cream is a sphere with a radius of 1 ¼ inches.

Will there be more ice cream or more root beer in the float? Explain.

Filling the glass to one-half inch from the top means the total volume of root beer and ice cream is about 39.27 in.3. Each scoop of ice cream has a volume of about 8.2 in.3, so 3 scoops has a volume of about 24.6 in.3. There will be about 14.7 in.3 of root beer in each float, so there will be more ice cream than root beer.
ACE 4-10
Suppose a scoop of ice cream is a sphere with a radius of 1 inch. How many scoops can be packed into the cone like the picture shown?
The scoop has a volume of π or about 4.2 in.3; the cone has a volume of (5π)/3, or about 5.2 in.3. The cone holds about 1.25 scoops.
ACE 4-11

Each of the number sentences models the formula for the volume of a figure you have worked with in this Unit. Name, sketch, and label the dimensions of each figure. Then, find the volume.

a. 2⅔ • 4⅘ • 3⅞

b. π • (2.2)2 • 6.5

c. ⅓π • (4.25)2 • 10
a. This calculation is for the volume of a rectangular prism with the dimensions shown below. The volume is 49⅗ cubic units.
b. This calculation is for the volume of a cylinder with a radius of 2.2 and a height of 6.5. The volume is approximately 98.8 cubic units.
c. This calculation is for the volume of a cone with a radius of 4.25 and a height of 10. The volume is approximately 189 cubic units.
ACE 4-12
Find the radius of a sphere with volume 250 in.3.
Radius is approximately 3.9 inches.
ACE 4-13

A square pyramid is related to a square prism in the same way that a cone is related to a cylinder. Suppose that a square pyramid is enclosed in a square prism with base sides s and height h. What formula would you expect to give the volume of the pyramid?
ACE 4-14
a. What is the volume of this rectangular prism?
b. What is the volume of this rectangular pyramid?

a. Volume is 120 cm3

b. Volume is ⅓ of 120 cm3 or 40 cm3
ACE 4-15
The prices and dimensions of several school movie theater popcorn containers are shown below. Which container has the best unit rate of most popcorn per dollar?

The pyramid has a volume 4,000 cm3, which is 1,000 cm3 of popcorn per dollar; the cone has a volume of 1,000π ≈ 3,142 cm3, which is about 1,257 cm3 of popcorn per dollar; the cylinder has a volume of 1,280π ≈ 4,021 cm3, which is about 1,072 cm3 of popcorn per dollar; the prism has a volume of 3,600 cm3, which is 1,029 cm3 of popcorn per dollar. Thus, the cone has the best value of popcorn per dollar.
Connections
ACE 4-16

Suppose that you are shown two packages for sugar.

a. Which package has the greater surface area? How do you know?

b. Which package has the greater volume? How do you know?

a. The rectangular prism has a surface area of 1,128 cm2; the closed cylinder has a surface area of 290π, or about 911 cm2. The prism has a greater surface area.

b. The rectangular prism has a volume of 2,016 cm3; the closed cylinder has a volume of 600π, or about 1,884 cm3. The prism has a greater volume.
ACE 4-17

Carlos plans to build a hot tub with a depth of 4 feet.

a. If Carlos wants to build a circular hot tub with a volume of 1,000 ft3. What is a good approximation for the radius of the tub?

b. If Carlos decides he would rather build a rectangular hot tub that holds 400 ft3 of water. What could be the dimensions of the base of Carlos’s hot tub?

a. The radius will be about 9 feet.

b. Answers will vary. The dimensions of the base could be any pair of numbers whose product is 100.
ACE 4-18

Five students measured the height of the same cylinder. Their measurements are listed below. What is the average of the measurements?

  • 5.1 centimeters
  • 4.9 centimeters
  • 5.15 centimeters
  • 5.15 centimeters
  • 4.85 centimeters
The average is 5.03 centimeters.
ACE 4-19

Each number sentence shows calculations required to find the surface area of a three-dimensional figure. Name the figure the number sentence describes. Find the surface area.

a. (2 • 4 • 8.5) + (2 • 8.5 • 7.25) + (2 • 7.25 • 4)

b. 2 • (4 • 8.5 + 8.5 • 7.25 + 7.25 • 4)

c. 2(π • 42) + 8 π • 8.5

a. This calculation is for the surface area of a rectangular prism with dimensions 4 × 8.5 × 7.25. In that case, S.A. = 249.25 Note the parenthesis are not needed in the expression. They are add for visual clarity.

b. This calculation is equivalent to the previous exercise. It is the surface area of a rectangular prism with dimensions 4 × 8.5 × 7.25. The surface area is again 249.25.

c. This calculation is for the surface area of a cylinder—twice the area of a circular base that has a radius of 4 and the product of the circumference and a height of 8.5 for the lateral surface. The surface area is 100π.
ACE 4-20
What two-dimensional shapes appear if you slice a cone as shown on each figure?

The vertical cut exposes two triangles; the slant cut reveals two parabolic regions (students won’t know this term, but should be expected to sketch curves that have a parabolic shape); the horizontal cut exposes two circles.
ACE 4-21
What two-dimensional shapes appear if you slice a sphere horizontally as shown on each figure?
In both cases, the cuts expose circles. The cut along the equator reveals circles whose centers are also the center of the sphere. These are called great circles.
ACE 4-22
Kaiya measures the circumference of a sphere and finds that it is about 54 centimeters. What is the volume of the sphere?
The radius is 54/(2π ) ≈ 8.6, so the volume is about π (8.6)3 ≈ 2,659 cm3.
ACE 4-23

Wigwam, wickiup, and wetu are all names of living structures used by some Native Americans. Tribes like the Ojibwe and Wampanoag would use natural resources such as young trees and bark to build the structures.
We might think of the shape of a wigwam is a half a cylinder with half a hemisphere at each end. What is the volume of this shape?

Volume Half Cylinder + Volume Hemisphere

½ (8π72)+ ½ (⅔ • 14π72)

½ (1231.5) + ½ (1436.76) = 1334.13 ft3
ACE 4-24

Suppose that a square prism and a square pyramid each have a base with sides of 3 inches and a volume of 225 in.3.

a. What is the height of the prism?

b. What is the height of the pyramid?

a. Prism height is 25 inches

b. Pyramid height is 75 inches.
ACE 4-25

The Mathletes are planning their own frozen yogurt sale. They must choose between the prism and the square pyramid shown below, both of which have the same cost. Which container should they use? Explain.
Possible answer: The pyramid holds less frozen yogurt (75 cm3) than the cube (101 cm3), so the Mathletes should use the pyramid.
Extensions
ACE 4-26

A cylindrical can is packed securely in a box as shown.

a. Find the radius and height of the can.

b.What is the volume of the empty space between the can and the box?

c. Find the ratio of the volume of the can to the volume of the box.

d. Make up a similar example with a can and a box of different sizes. What is the ratio of the volume of your can to the volume of your box?

e. How does the ratio you found in part (d.) compare with the ratio you found in part (c.)?

a. Radius is 1cm and height is 10 cm.

b. Volume of empty space is 40 – 10π, or about 8.6 cm3.

c. Ratio of can volume to box volume is π/4.

d. Dimensions will vary. The ratio will be π to 4.

e. The ratio will always be π/4 Since the radius of the cylinder is s/2, and both figures have the same height:
ACE 4-27

A 60˚ slice was cut out of this cylinder.

a. What is the volume now? Show your thinking.

b. How does this compare to the original volume?

a. A 60˚ slice out of 360˚ leaves 5/6 of the volume.

Original volume: 10π42 ≈ 502.65

5/6(502.65) = 418.88 cm3

b. The volume is 5/6 the size of the original. 300˚/360˚ = 5/6
ACE 4-28

Ted made a scale model of a submarine for his science class.

a. What is the volume of Ted’s model submarine in cubic inches?

b. If 1 inch on the model represents 20 feet in the actual submarine, what is the volume of the actual submarine in cubic feet?

a. VolumeHemisphere + VolumeCylinder + VolumeCone

½ (⅔ • 32 π • 6) + 32 π • 12 + ⅓ • 32 π • 4 ≈

56.55 + 339.29 + 37.7 = 433.54 in3

b. Since 1 inch : 20 feet, the volume of the real submarine is about 203(434), or 3,472,000 ft3.
ACE 4-29

Julian bought a new mailbox with the following dimensions.

Find the volume and surface area of the mailbox.

Volume Rectangular Prism + Volume Half-Cylinder

(8 • 10 • 15) + ½ (42 • π • 15)

1200 + 377 = 1577 in3
ACE 4-30

An exercise training ball is packaged very tightly in a box. It is called a ball, but the shape is a hemisphere (half sphere).

a. What is the volume of the box? What is the volume of the hemisphere?

b. What percent of the box is not used?

a. Vbox: 3 • 3 • 1.5 = 13.5 ft3

Volume Hemishpere : ½ (⅔ • 1.52 π • 3) = ½ (14.14) = 7.07 ft3

b. 7.07 out of 13.5 is about 0.524 or 52%.
ACE 4-31

Pyramids are named for the shapes of their bases. The left shape below is a triangular pyramid, the center shape is a square pyramid, and the right shape is a pentagonal pyramid.

Suppose you have a set of five pyramids whose bases are all regular polygons. The bases have 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 sides. All pyramids have the same base perimeter, and all have the same height (with the top vertex directly above the center of the base).

a. Describe a method for finding the surface area of a regular pyramid.

b. How will the surface areas of the five pyramids be related to each other?

c. How will the volumes of the five pyramids be related to each other?

d. How would the surface area and volume of a cone with the same base perimeter and height compare to the surface areas and volumes of the five pyramids?

a. The surface area of any such pyramid can be found by finding the sum of the areas of the polygonal faces. The lateral faces are triangles with the same base and height (the slant height drawn from the top of the pyramid perpendicular to an edge of the base). The bases will be different polygons. If the base shape is not a special polygon for which you know an area formula, it is always possible to decompose the polygon into triangles.

b. Based on the earlier experiment with prisms of constant perimeter, students should conclude that the base areas of the pyramids will increase as the number of sides increases. For the triangular faces connecting the base to the top vertex, the heights will also increase as the number of sides increases. While the area of each lateral triangle will decrease, the lateral area and the surface area will be greater.

c. Since the area of the base increases as the number of sides increases, and the height is constant, the volume also increases as the number of sides increases.

d. A cone will have maximum surface area and volume since both measures increase as the number of sides of the base increases. As the number of sides of the base increases, the shape of the pyramid approaches a cylinder. (Note: Remind students of Problem 2.1.)
ACE 4-32

Some Inuit people build temporary dwellings called igloo, or aputiak, shaped like hemispheres (halves of a sphere). Some Hopi people in Arizona build adobes shaped like rectangular prisms.

a. If the inner diameter of an Inuit igloo is 20 feet, what is the area of its floor? What is the volume of the inner space?

b. What dimensions for a Hopi dwelling would give the same floor area and the same volume of living space as the Inuit igloo?

a. Area of floor is π (102) ≈ 314 ft2;

volume is ½(4/3)π(103) ≈ 2,094 ft3

b. There are many possible combinations of dimensions that will give the same floor area and total volume of inner space if the figure is a rectangular prism.

For example, a square floor with sides of approximately 17.7 feet would have the same area. In that case, the height of the room would be about 6.7 feet. In fact, for any combination of dimensions for a rectangular floor with product 314, the height will always be 6.7 feet.
ACE 4-33

For each shape, find the dimensions that will most closely fit inside a cubic box with 10-centimeter edges. Then find the volume of that shape. Assume that the base of each shape lies on a face of the cube.

a. Sphere

b. Cylinder

c. Cone

d. Pyramid

a. The largest sphere has a radius of 5 centimeters and a volume of about 524 cm3.

b. The largest cylinder has a radius of 5 cm, a height of 10 cm, and a volume of about 785 cm3.

c. The largest cone has a radius of 5 cm, a height of 10 cm, and a volume of about 262 cm3.

d. The largest pyramid has a square base with edges 10 cm long, a height of 10 cm, and a volume of about 333 cm3.
ACE 4-34

It may not be possible to wrap a ball smoothly with a piece of paper, but the surface area of a sphere is related to the area of a circle. You can discover this relationship with a hands-on experiment.

• Measure the diameter and radius of a spherical object.
  • Make at least five paper circles that have the same diameter and radius as the sphere. Refer to these as radius circles.
  • Tape radius circles, or pieces of the circles, on the sphere to cover it as fully as possible without overlap. Keep track of the number of radius circles needed.

a. Repeat the experiment for multiple values of radius and surface area. About how many radius circles are needed to cover each sphere?

b. What is the approximate area of the radius circles you used to cover a sphere of radius r?

c. What does that observation suggest about a formula relating surface area S.A. and radius r for a sphere?

d. Use your formula from part (c.) to complete the table.

e. What pattern do you see in the surface area as the radius increases?

f. When the radius is doubled, how does the surface area increase?

g. When the radius is tripled, how does the surface area increase?

h. How is the change in surface area from scaling up the radius of a sphere similar to the patterns you noticed when you scaled up the 1-2-3 boxes in Problem 1.4?

a. Answers may vary. Every trial should result in about 4 radius circles

b. The approximate area of 4 radius circles is 4 πr2.

c. S.A. = 4 πr2

d.

e. The surface area increases very rapidly as radius increases. In fact, each successive increase of 1 in the radius causes increasingly larger growth in the surface area.

f. When the radius is doubled, the surface area increases by a factor of 4.

g. When the radius is tripled, the surface area increases by a factor of 9.

h. The change in surface area is the square of the scale factor; if the radius is scaled up by a factor f, the surface area is multiplied by f2. The pattern of growth is the same as it was for the surface areas of 1–2–3 compost boxes and for areas of two-dimensional figures in the Unit Covering and Surrounding.
ACE 4-35

Chuck is designing a paper cone. He draws a quarter circle that has the diameter of 10 inches. Then he rolls it to make a cone shape. He wants to draw another circle to cover the base of the cone, what is the diameter of the circle? Explain.

2.5 inches. The length of the curved edge of a quarter circle is the same as the circumference of the circle for the base. It is because the curved edge of a quarter circle will form a circle when you roll the paper to make a cone. The circumference of the big circle is 10 x π ≈ 31.4 and a quarter of it is 31.4 x ¼ = 7.85. If a circle has a circumference of 7.85, then its diameter is 7.85 ÷ π ≈ 7.85 ÷ 3.14 ≈ 2.5.

2.5 inches. The circumference of the circle for the base is the same as a quarter of the circumference of circle used to make the cone. The curved edge of a quarter circle will form a circle when you roll the paper to make a cone.

The circumference of the big circle is 10 • π ≈ 31.4 and a quarter of it is 31.4 • ¼ = 7.85. If a circle has a circumference of 7.85, then its diameter is 7.85 ÷ π ≈ 7.85 ÷ 3.14 ≈ 2.5.
